Retrieve geographic coordinates

Source: R/code-geography.R
geocode_tags.Rd

geocode_tags() retrieves geographic coordinates (i.e., latitude and longitude) based on the locations listed in Twitter user profiles. geocode_tags() pulls from the OpenCage Geocoding API, which requires a OpenCage Geocoding API Key. You can easily secure a key through OpenCage; read more here. We recommend saving your OpenCage Geocoding API Key in the .Renviron file as OPENCAGE_KEY. You can quickly access this file using the R code usethis::edit_r_environ(scope='user'). Add a line to this file that reads: OPENCAGE_KEY="PasteYourOpenCageKeyInsideTheseQuotes". To read your key into R, use the code Sys.getenv('OPENCAGE_KEY'). Note that the geocode_tags() function retrieves your saved API key automatically and securely. Once you've saved the .Renviron file, quit your R session and restart. The function geocode_tags() will work for you from now on.

geocode_tags(df)

Arguments

df

A dataframe or tibble

Value

A tibble of geographic coordinates (i.e., latitude and longitude) that can then be used to plot locations on a map

Details

This function requires authentication; please see vignette("setup", package = "tidytags")

See also

OpenCage Geocoding API Documentation

Blog posts from Jesse Sadler and Laura Ellis may also provide additional inspiration for geocoding.

The ggmap package can provide additional functionality for visualizing geographic data.

Examples


if (FALSE) {

example_url <- "18clYlQeJOc6W5QRuSlJ6_v3snqKJImFhU42bRkM_OX8"
tmp_df <- pull_tweet_data(read_tags(example_url), n = 10)
tmp_geo_coords <- geocode_tags(tmp_df)
tmp_geo_coords

if (requireNamespace("sf", quietly = TRUE)) {
  locations <- sf::st_as_sf(
    tmp_geo_coords,
    coords = c(x = "longitude", y = "latitude"),
    crs = 4326
  )
}

if (requireNamespace("mapview", quietly = TRUE)) {
  mapview::mapview(locations)
}

}
